urls.title: Record funding for flood defences in England as climate crisis worsens risks
urls.description: The government will spend a record ¬£5.2bn on reducing flooding in England over the next six years, as the climate crisis increases the risk to homes and businesses. The Environment Agency will spend ¬£860m next year to support more than 1,000 schemes, with significant funds for Yorkshire and the Humber and the north-west, regions that have been hit hard in recent years. Ministers also announced tighter guidance to deter the building of new homes in flood-prone areas and changes to a government-backed insurance scheme to allow flooded homeowners to be paid to better protect their homes. The government said 336,000 properties would be better protected by 2027, helping to avoid ¬£32bn in damage to the economy and reducing the national flood risk by up to 11%. The EA said, however, that not all flooding would be prevented and that people should check their flood risk. The moves were broadly welcomed, but some experts said maintenance budgets for flood defences would also need to rise and tha
